bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: A Benjamin Swartz (alternate name: Benjamin F.Swartz), enlisted in the 5th Pennsylvania Calvary, Company F. His rank upon entering the regiment is listed as "Saddl.", his discharge rank was Sergeant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: These letters are written from or on behalf of Benjamin Schwartz, who was stationed in Virginia with the 5th Pennsylvania Calvary, Company F. The letters primarily document a brother's concern over his family's health and money he sends to his sister. There is limited discussion of skirmishes, troop movement, taking and being taken prisoner, and recurrent predictions that the war will end soon. Schwartz mentions that the Union camp at Williamsburg, Virginia was burned by rebel forces.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in chronological order.

did.unittitle: Item 1: Letter, Camp Griffin, to Sister Libby 11/23/1861

scopecontent.p: "fixing up things to keep us a little warm" Went to two reviews, one at Bailey's Cross Roads.

did.unittitle: Item 2: Letter, Camp Griffin, to Dear Sister 3/5/1862
Item 3: Letter, Williamsburg, to Dear Sister 11/21/1862

scopecontent.p: Concerned about money sent, busy building winter quarters, notes that they have many new horses and recruits, predicts war will not last long.

did.unittitle: Item 4: Letter, Williamsburg, to Dear Sister 4/23/1863

scopecontent.p: Hard week, rebels burned Union camp, but repulsed them, captured a number of rebel prisoners.

did.unittitle: Item 5: Letter, Williamsburg, to My Dear Sister 5/1/1863

scopecontent.p: Predicts rebels will have to give up as "they are near starved[?] out and played out to nothing" "was taken prisoner and made my escape."

did.unittitle: Item 6: Letter, Williamsburg, to My Dear Sister 6/10/1863

scopecontent.p: Describes march to Richmond, foiled plan to burn city.
Their camp has moved many times.

did.unittitle: Item 9: Letter, Camp near Portsmouth, To: My Dear Sister 4/26/1864
Item 11: Letter, Camp Near Jones Landing to My dear Sister Elizabeth Schwartz, North Buffalo, Erie County, N. Y. 8/21/1864

scopecontent.p: Surprised that Home Guard was called out to defend Buffalo, describes prowess of Company F.

did.unittitle: Item 12: Letter, Richmond to Dear Sister 4/29/1865
Item 13: Letter, Sollomon City, Saline County, Kansas to Dear Sister 3/3/1869

scopecontent.p: Discusses cold weather and high water. Folder also contains a single sheet, with paper and ink similar to letter above, asking for Henry's location, noting the loss of Eve's husband.

did.unittitle: Series 2: (Item 14) Letter of Henry F. Jackson, Deep Bottom, Va. 3/25/1865

scopecontent.p: Stationery printed with "U. S. Christian Commission." handwritten underneath "and hard tack." Sent money, "Benjamin has gone out on a raid."

did.unittitle: Item 15: envelope addressed to Miss. Elizabeth Schwartz, Williamsvill[e], Erie Co., New York 10/18/n.y.
Item 16: envelope addressed to Elizabeth Schwartz, Williamsville, Erie Co., N[ew] York 9/13/1862

scopecontent.p: Envelope addressed to Miss. Elizabeth Schwartz, Williamsville, Erie County, N. Y. has word "Coyote" written on it.
